Message.Title: TSMC Prepares for More Shocks
Message.Msg: Earlier in 2013, the news broke that Altera was to use Intel to build fpga's at the 14nm node after dealing exclusively with Taiwanese foundry TSMC for 20 years. The move shocked TSMC. The company's chief executive Dr Morris Chang noted during an analysts' call with New Electronics: "I very much regret Altera's decision to work on 14nm with Intel. From New Electronics

Topic.Title: ARMH is flying...intc crawling

Message.Msg: ARM drops 9 percent last week. Recovers 2 percent on a big NASDAQ day and you say nothing has changed. Haswell arrives next Monday and Samsung is using Intel processors in a new tablet and you say nothing has changed. Have you checked with your eye doctor? It appears that something is wrong with your vision. Brain?

Topic.Title: ARMH is flying...intc crawling

Message.Msg: Okay, so here's the deal. Intel is a $120B market cap company. ARMH is a $21B market cap company. When Intel moves 1%, it gains/loses $1.2B in value, but when ARM moves 1% it gains/loses $210M. So naturally it is much harder to see larger % gains in INTC than in ARM, since ARMH is smaller. If you want volatility, either own Intel with in the money LEAPs, or just sell Intel and go for a small cap.

Topic.Title: The Haswell News Cycle Ramp

Message.Msg: Off to a nice start...

Message.Title: Coming Up
Message.Msg: June 3: Intel to release Haswell - In the final countdown stage. June 4: Computex Opening Keynote-Tom Kilroy, executive vice president and general manager, Intel's Sales and Marketing Group, will deliver a keynote on Intel's vision for continued innovation to reinvent people's computing experiences across a range of devices. June 4: Computex-Computing Reinvented Satellite Event and Media Q&A-Kirk Skaugen, senior vice president and general manager of the PC Client Group, will host the computing reinvented satellite event where he'll demonstrate and provide details on the new experiences delivered by 4th generation Intel Core processor-based Ultrabooks, laptops, desktops and all-in-one devices. June 5: Computex-Mobile and Communications Satellite Event and Media Q&A-Hermann Eul, VP/GM, Mobile and Communications Group, will host a satellite event to showcase the growing number of tablets for Windows and Android, smartphones and other ultra-mobile devices with Intel Inside. June 4-6: Dell Enterprise Forum-Enterprise Solutions Keynote: Built for Where Business Is Going June 10-14: Apple's WWDC - Macs about to get a major upgrade thanks to Intel’s new “Iris” graphics processors? June 20: Samsung announces new Windows and Android products in London. June 26-28: Microsoft's Build Developer Conference - Rumors of next Surface Pro announcement

Topic.Title: ARMH is flying...intc crawling

Message.Msg: INTC now outperforming ARMH. ARMH stock IS broken, and people are taking the opportunity to short it. See the historical charts of CRUS, FIO, and MLNX to understand what is going on. People want out/are shorting ARMH. I added to my short this morning.

Topic.Title: ARMH is flying...intc crawling

Message.Msg: I just looked at the two and ARMH is up 1.4% and INTC is up 1.3%. 0.1% is not the difference between "flying" and "crawling". INTC is a member of just about every index and therefore a member of every ETF. ETF creation unit accounts for about 40% of Intel share volume. ARMH ... not so much and therefore more volatile. INTC has a very liquid and very aggressively traded options market with most spreads of a penny. There is substantial trading to arbitrage the Intel dividend. Nov 3rd, 2011, the naked short interest jumped over 1.7m shares in one day. A couple days earlier, as part of a dividend scheme, 600,000 deep ITM Call options traded. The options are being played. The spread on ARMH options is 5 cents AT ITS best. As you suggest, comparing the two, in terms of liquidity, is silly.

Message.Title: Economic data is coming in better than expected... as you know.
Message.Msg: shorts... it's time to cover. you're running out of time. you're going to lose on fabrication. 22nm FinFET is better than 28nm planar. 14nm FinFET is better than 20nm planar. A P/E of 12 is more attractive than a P/E of 75. A PEG of 1.17 is better than a PEG of 2.23. trading at 2.5 times book value is better than trading at 10 times book. ARM currently owns the market, yes. But give me an argument for the next 2 years. look ahead and tell me what you see.

Message.Title: Time to initiate an ARMH short?
Message.Msg: I fear shorting stock because, when long you can only lose your whole investment, but short you can lose in principle an infinite amount of money. Yet, I agree with the logic of my colleagues in here, Weaver and Ashraf...ARMH is doomed and the stock belongs under $10 or something. I am very tempted to do what I have never done before...short it... I don't want to buy puts...puts expire in finite time and you need precision in guesstimating when to sell and buy them. (I am short many puts, leaps actually, on INTC since that is logically equivalent to a long position and I have confidence in INTC over time...and, Weaver, I went short INTC puts when this thing was last crawling to $30 and you were pumping like a jockey...all those positions, except my Jan 14, 30's are in the green..showing spectacular profits). But short stock and you can lose in principle an infinite amount of money. ... I repeat: short stock and you can lose in principle an infinite amount of money. .. hear that INTC shorts? You WILL lose in due course. INTC maybe crawling, but it is heading way way up in due course.

Topic.Title: Time to initiate an ARMH short?

Message.Msg: ARM just doesn't have a lot of upside risk at this point + it's a large cap + zero take-over risk. Risk/reward at ~$46 is quite good, and I think the upcoming Intel/AMD tag-team assault on the ARM stronghold should help deflate expectations quite a bit.

Topic.Title: Time to initiate an ARMH short?

Message.Msg: Shorting Intel here is just plain stupid. ARM's business on the other hand couldn't even cover one Intel dividend payment, lol

Message.Msg: Basically says tablets will take over all of PC markets by 2015. Meanwhile, Intel management says nothing to defend itself..New CEO same as old CEO. No leadership.

Topic.Title: IDC report today crushed Intel/PCs/laptop forecasts

Message.Msg: IDC also says that tablet volumes are exploding. Since IDC considers a PC with a removable keyboard a "tablet", guess why PC volumes are going down and tablet volumes are going up. It is because IDC is counting PC's as tablets. Using the IDC definition, the MSFT Surface Pro is a tablet. Intel management should not waste their time with stuff like this. The new CEO is very good. "No leadership"? Maybe not according to your definition. Not many agree with you however. From iDC website .... "•IDC considers all LCD-based slate devices with screens between 7 and 16 inches as tablets, regardless of whether or not they include a removable keyboard (such as the Surface RT). Convertible devices with non-removable keyboards (such as Lenovo's Yoga) are not counted as Tablets. "

Topic.Title: IDC report today crushed Intel/PCs/laptop forecasts

Message.Msg: Some tablets are thin-clients and some tablets are PC's. A thin-client has a browser-based operating system and depends on an internet connection for much of its application. A PC can install and run major applications without an internet connection. To say that tablets are replacing PC's when some tablets are PC's is a major problem with the data .

Topic.Title: IDC report today crushed Intel/PCs/laptop forecasts

Message.Msg: That is not the topic of the thread. The topic is the IDC forecasts and the IDC definition of PC and tablet. If the "bad" IDC news is taken without understanding what is meant, there is strong potential for confusion. That is what backbay counts on. I was just pointing out that the PC ship numbers are deceptive. The market will go down in the future. When the market goes down, Intel will go down. How much drop, from how much higher than right now and when the drop starts are not known but there are lots of opinions. I don't have the answers to these questions but I also know that no one else has them either. One other opinion that I have that is probably different is that I think that Intel will trade with the market but will have a generally stronger RSI. If the market drops 5%, I think that Intel will not drop 5%. Intel will probably drop something less .... like 4.8%. My reasoning is based on the steady shorting that was necessary to push Intel down from $29 to $19.23. You won't find more shorts and some will start covering. Second is the new products that are scheduled for intro. I have cash and I have some downside hedges. Down will not be fun but I think I will weather it OK.

Topic.Title: IDC report today crushed Intel/PCs/laptop forecasts

Message.Msg: Android, Blackberry, Chrome, iOS, Tizen, Windows Phone, and Windows RT are thin-client operating systems. Chrome is included because it is available on a tablet as the OS. Android, Blackberry, iOS, and Tizen have run, or run, or will run, on both smartphones and tablets. So then Windows Phone is included with Windows Phone and Windows RT being variants of each other. DOS, Linux, Mac, Unix, and full Windows are PC operating systems .

Topic.Title: Structural Change In The Mobile Processor Marketplace: Intel Wins; ARM, AMD Lose

Message.Msg: In the comments section, Fidgewinkle had this to say: "Digital made some really fast processors using really cool technology like dynamic logic, but they missed the whole picture. "My engineering experience through similar success and failure to Digital taught me that trying to engineer the fanciest chip possible lands you in deep kimchi when it comes to manufacturing, which is what hoses you in the end. It is a pity that no one at Digital ever figured that out. "The difference between Digital and Intel is that Intel will going forward likely have the fastest chip, best power efficiency, the fastest time to market and the highest yield. Digital, had probably only one of these things going for it. Certainly not more than two." My Comment: Usually people back down when you throw out "Digital failed even though it had excellent engineering" but Fidgewinkle answers in a unique way that Intel has covered the four corners of engineering excellence.

Topic.Title: ANOTHER 10" ANDROID TABLET INTEL WIN: ASUS ME302C

Message.Msg: Clover Trail+ will put a lot of price pressure on arm-base device makers. Remember Clover Trail+ is competitive with the very best arm SoC out there, but it is built on intel's much depreciated 32nm process. Normally, Intel would usually get rid of these older process but now, they are taking advantage of them and using them to make super cheap SoCs. I would not be surprise to see clover trail+ devices priced at $150 or so. This will really put the pressure on arm.
